X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=151231063
X-Yahoo-Profile: joeraii

> You say that the evaluation methods differ, but note that "loose"
> evaluation more accurately analyzes the strength of a player.  You
> note that players evolved using "strict" evaluation are easily
> defeated by a sub-optimal player (such as a random player).  Why then
> did you use "strict" evaluation as your primary mode of evaluation?
> Time?  Computing resources?

Mainly this was for consistency of evaluation. If a network recieved a
score of 90% once, it should score 90% again on the next trial. I forget
exactly why this was important (something to do with the data collection).
Also you are right, it takes less time to compute, and when I was using
the tic-tac-toe domain I was more concerned about just getting evolution
to occur, rather than evolution of something useful.


> "This example network solves tic-tac- toe, only missing one game out
> of 10 against the perfect opponent (the genetic algorithm converged
> on the perfect solution 200 generations later)."
>
> You say that the network "solves" Tic-Tac-Toe, but it's only being
> evaluated against a perfect player.  And by "missing one game out of
> 10", I'm assuming that you mean the evolved player lost 1 and tied 9
> against the perfect player.  Is that right?

"Solves" is used very loosely here. It solves tic-tac-toe in the sense
that it cannot get much better playing against the strict opponent. You
are right it loses one out of 10 games.

> My main question is, if a network can tie 90% of its games against an
> optimal player, would we say it has solved Tic-Tac-Toe?  What if the
> same network loses 85% of its games against a random player?

It depends on what your goal is. Mine was to demonstrate that Modular NEAT
actually evolved things. Truly solving tic-tac-toe I think would require
always tying the perfect player (in all of the perfect game trees), and
always playing to win against non-perfect players.

The Pollack paper you mentioned seems like a good idea, but really the
best would be to have it play against all of the possible combinations of
opponents moves and calculate its fitness from that.

Joe

Joseph Reisinger
